A. When White touched the knight, White took his pen and intended to write down 30 Ne7. After White put the knight on d8, he kept looking at the board with his pen hanging in the air. This was indeed an unpleasant move to face in his slight time trouble.
B. Now the bishop that White failed to capture causes White a lot of trouble. As the following variations show, Black has a very strong attack no matter what White does.
C. After the skirmish in the centre, the white queen is brought into the struggle with effect.
D. Black has a lot of space on the K-side and he can start counterplay by g6-g5 and f5-f4.
Analyze step by step and explain your reasoning.
Finish with a single line formatted EXACTLY as:

question:
You are given a chess position in FEN: 3rr1k1/pbp2pn1/1p2pqp1/4R1Np/3P1P2/2PB3Q/PP4PP/4R1K1 w - - 7 22
A player makes the move: g2g4
Select the commentary that best describes this position and move.

Options:
A. This pin is not effective, but I can hardly recommend something better!
B. Black decides to fix the pawn structure and restrict White's light-squared bishop. However, this decision has a clear drawback: now White gets good attacking prospects due to a space advantage.
C. That is modern chess nowadays! After playing three consecutive moves with the same piece and getting it back to its initial square all White has achieved is now the black pawn is placed on h6 instead of h7. In pre-computer era such moves would have been considered as coffeehouse chess but thanks to strong computers our perspective has changed a lot and we now see such lines at the top level. Is h6 is a weakness or a useful move? That depends on which setup White is going to adopt next. For instance, if he now plays Be2 then Black will play e5 and surely then h6 will be useful as it stops
D. No more preparation moves, the attack has to go on! It looks doubled edged, because even the white king's position is weakened.
Analyze step by step and explain your reasoning.
Finish with a single line formatted EXACTLY as:
FINAL ANSWER: <answer>

B. This is a very interesting move order, ruling out a6-b5 systems of the Modern defense due to the possibility of going into a favourable King's Indian after c2-c4. Usually it all ends up in a Classical Pirc.

B. After long reflection White chose this move, planning a further queen sacrifice that worked so well in the game. However, 16 Rad1 could possibly cost White a point, at least when playing against a computer.

D. This move highlights the drawbacks of Black's pawn advance. The h5-pawn is weak and its sacrifice does not help much. Black spent almost all the remaining time (around 20 minutes) and went for a desperate sacrifice which eventually succeeded. It seems to Black that Black's position is already beyond saving.
Analyze step by step and explain your reasoning.

Having thought for almost half an hour White finally admitted that White's king would never be safe on any of the diagonals a7-g1 or a8-h1, because of Black's strong X-Ray attack by queen and bishop. Having realised that this was a fact, it was easy to decide that the king should move upwards to g3.

question:

A player makes the move: f1c4
Select the commentary that best describes this position and move.

Options:
A. A very rare move intended to avoid the main lines, which can also be played on move 2 Of course the intention is to continue with g4, but 2 h3 is somewhat more solid than the immediate 2 g4, when the most principled move for Black is to take the gambit.
B. When preparing for the game, White noticed that White's opponent has a wide repertoire. White's team mates had warned White that he is well prepared in theoretical lines and White must confess that White did not feel like facing the Volga/Benko Gambit on that day. The game move does not promise an advantage, but leaves both players on their own at a very early stage, which was precisely White's intention.
C. We have transposed to a normal line of the Queen's Gambit Declined Exchange Variation. More often you see the move e3 instead of Qc2. So Black tries to take advantage of this fact by developing his knight to a6 and threatening Nb4.
D. This form of the gambit is almost out of date. Chigorin, however, ocassionaly plays it, and with success. h4 instead, bringing about the Allgaier or Kieseritzky, is now more frequently adopted.
Analyze step by step and explain your reasoning.

A player makes the move: h6h5
Select the commentary that best describes this position and move.

Options:
A. A very interesting position, at least from a technical point of view. Black has managed to clear off 3 sets of minor pieces, as well as the a- and b-pawns. All this speaks in favour of a draw, but White does have a very visible plus in the sense that his knight will settle on c4 or d5. That in itself is not enough to make Black's position collapse, so a lot is going to depend on how White can improve his position, intensifying the pressure. This position perhaps is not Black's last chance, but still a very crucial one.
B. A mistake as it affords the blindfold player the opportunity of breaking through on the other flank. As Black's object is to draw if possible, he should have withheld his King's wing so as to block the opposite Pawns and by this retaining his guard on all sides.
C. Now White must act quickly as if Black can get his king over to b7 he would have a theoretical draw even without his g6-pawn.
D. and we arrive at the consequences that I mentioned on the last move. According to my understanding of chess, this kind of structure is somewhat better for White if there is still the possibility to fianchetto the bishop on g2. Either Black made a mistake with his 6th move, or my understanding might need an upgrade. Statistically speaking, the latter is more probable.
Analyze step by step and explain your reasoning.
Finish with a single line formatted EXACTLY as:

Select the commentary that best describes this position and move.

Options:
A. Black intends to slowly push the enemy king to the centre. Therefore, he takes the f2-square under control in order to check on g1 without allowing the interposing of the white king.
B. The endgames with opposite coloured bishops have strong drawish tendencies. Also, Black had just a few seconds to make his last 6 moves, so, it might be the case that White felt that he was out of danger. However, this endgame is tricky, and White has to play carefully to hold it. First of all, White's queenside pawns are completely useless: while he has the numerical advantage of 4 vs. 2, he can't create a single passed pawn. Black, on the other hand, has a pawn majority in the centre-kingside with 3 vs. 1 It should
C. This is an endgame both players went for. White has a knight for 3 pawns which is a very fine material allocation for the second player, but he does have to watch out a little bit, as the a6 pawn is fixed by the a5 pawn and if the knight is ever to land on b4, Black could get under pressure. But that will never happen... or will it?
D. White probably thought that Black would have difficulty castling. In fact, Black demonstrates that his king is better placed than if it had already castled, as the position is tending toward an endgame and his king is already in the centre. Black's central pawn position -- or lack thereof -- is typical of the Steinitzian precedents, but here White still has ad-pawn. question:
You are given a chess position in FEN: 3r3r/ppp1bk1p/5p2/6p1/3p2b1/P2P4/1PPNNPPP/R3R1K1 b - - 0 19
A player makes the move: c7c5
Select the commentary that best describes this position and move.

Options:
A. Black's pieces are more active and he has more space on the queenside and also White's e1-bishop is not coming into the game soon. Black wanted to push Black's pawns on the queenside starting with a5, but didn't like the fact that White can respond with Qb3. So before expanding on the queenside it made sense to bring Black's knight to a better place: c5.
B. A surprise, as White have never seen Black play this line before. It is a solid opening for Black, though White can play aggressive and try to take advantage of the weakness on black squares in the centre (d6-e7) by playing d4. But White preferred to play more solidly in this very important last round.
C. Suddenly Black's solid construction on the queenside falls apart.

A player makes the move: d4d5
Select the commentary that best describes this position and move.

Options:
A. White absolutely dominates the board. White has at least two good plans to improve the position. One of them is to carry out a4-a5, thus, attacking Black's weaknesses on the queenside. Another one, is to centralize White's heavy pieces, threatening with invasion through the centre.
B. This direction in the Fianchetto is getting popularity recently. Black's idea is rather simple- he prepares a very important advance in the centre d5, which in case of exchange on d5 allows Black to equalize without problems, while after 11 c5 the pawn on d5 will restrict the light-squared bishop on g2. The main drawback of this line is that after 12 c6 Black will have weaknesses on c6 and c5. So the following play will be concentrated around these weaknesses.
C. Although isolated, this centre pawn assumes the role of a blockader.
D. White's general strategy is to play e4, which serves two purposes. Firstly, it may help to break up Black's solid central pawn structure, and secondly a later e4-e5 will gain space and may form the basis of a kingside attack, should Black castle on that side of the board. However, it is unusual for White to play e4 so quickly; the usual logic being that e4 cannot be prevented, so White may as well play 0-0 and bring his king into safety before taking action in the centre.
Analyze step by step and explain your reasoning.
Finish with a single line formatted EXACTLY as:

I believe that Black didn't analyse 9 Qb3 before the game and this time he couldn't find the right way over the board. As an improvement we can examine 10 Nbc6, 10 dxc4 and 10 Bg4. I think all these moves are sufficient to get an equal position.
D. One of the numerous forms of the Anti-Marshall variations. By advancing several of his pawns with just one step in a moment when the whole queen side is undeveloped, White intends to maintain the maximum of flexibility regarding the choice of the main plan.
Analyze step by step and explain your reasoning.

Another important source of counterplay lies on the queenside, where White's king is more vulnerable than it looks (and c1 is not always an ideal square).

However, in Sveshnikov Sicilian Black's position often contains a lot of hidden potential. The bishop pair, pawn majority in the center and the open g-file are strong arguments in his favour. Black's idea is to move the knight from g3 and push g4-g5, which will open the g-file and destroy the black king's defense. White, on the other hand, will try to develop his pieces and push c5, attacking White's center.

question:
You are given a chess position in FEN: rnbqkb1r/pp1ppppp/2p2n2/8/2P1P3/2N5/PP1P1PPP/R1BQKBNR b KQkq - 0 3
A player makes the move: d7d5
Select the commentary that best describes this position and move.

Options:
A. Of course, the exchange 31 exf5 gxf5 was dangerous, since in the end Black would have created two connected passed pawns in the center. But now Black gains the opportunity to restrict the enemy pieces still further and to launch an attack on the kingside.
B. Black uses his c-pawn as a lever to fight for the center, but White is pretty much in control already. Exchanges would work in Black's favor, leaving White with an isolated d-pawn. But White opts for more space instead.
C. Black doesn't forget about b6-b5, but intends to provide it later. First of all, he attacks White center. Later black's queen can be transfered to a safe square h5, where it can continue to attack White's spoiled pawn structure on the kingside.
D. Typical pawn sacrifice in this line which serves a couple of purposes. a) Black king will be forced to stay in the center since there is pressure against Bd7 b) White gets the excellent square c5 for his knights. c) Black's pawn structure is permanently damaged.
Analyze step by step and explain your reasoning.
Finish with a single line formatted EXACTLY as:
FINAL ANSWER: <answer>
Example format: FORMAT_EXAMPLE_PLACEHOLDER

Select the commentary that best describes this position and move.

Options:
A. By pinning the knight on f6 before Black has castled, and especially when the White king is already located on the critical wing, White lays himself open to a violent counterattack. Better is 6 Be3, now or on the next move.
B. Besides that it loses a crucial tempo, it is also the fact that the doubling of the pawns, as bad as it is, trades a piece, which is a big relief for Black, as he lacks space. So White is not sure he should fear it much.
C. This is one of the consequences of the pin: Black can exchange the dark-squared bishops.

In fact, Black demonstrates that his king is better placed than if it had already castled, as the position is tending toward an endgame and his king is already in the centre. Black's central pawn position -- or lack thereof -- is typical of the Steinitzian precedents, but here White still has ad-pawn. This gives him potentially better chances than the absence of both centre pawns, as the d-pawn may help support the knight at a variety of central posts, e.g., e4 or c4, although neither of these squares is absolutely secure

I really admire White's principled approach of going to the Berlin Endgame game after game and not backing down from the challenge even after some unsuccessful games from the White side, and even despite the fact that fashion seems to have gone in the other direction. Even though this wasn't a perfect game, considering the complexity of this game I think this game was played at a very high level. I really enjoyed analysing this game and commenting on it.

The resulting position is a rich positional battle: White has the option of playing dxc5 in some moment and trying to press against the hanging pawns (after bxc5), play against the isolani if Black takes on d4 (or after an eventual recapture with a piece on c5), and in both cases the bishop might have an active role being repositioned on g2 or h3. Black also has his counter-chances, as the hanging pawns seem promising for him, with all his forces well centralised, and he can prepare the advance c5-c4, making use of the queenside majority.
metadata.correct_text: The opening of the a-file, as it will be seen, is entirely to White's advantage, but the threatened 14 c5 was very disagreeable.

Instead of that, Black simply brings another piece into play, underlining the fact that he is 3 whole tempi ahead in the development, which makes the opening of the position undesirable for White, even if this would yield him an extra-pawn.

Options:
A. A step in the wrong direction, Black plays too passively. In order to increase his chances of a draw, it's essential to exchange as many pawns on the kingside as possible. This is because that as long as the kingside remains intact, White has the opportunity of creating an attack over there, to try and distract and break the blockade that Black has on the queenside.
B. Although this is not strictly a mistake (the position remains close to equal) Black shows that he will try to create a barrier in order to keep the white king out of d5. Activating the rook with Re6 followed by f5 and Re4 was a better way of handling the position.
C. Black knew a bit about the theory of this ending, but forgot the details long ago. Black remembered two main things and this was enough to hold the draw. Black should not allow his king to be cut off further away than on the g-file and besides it was dangerous to stay with the king on the queenside or on the back rank, as this would allow White to combining a mating attack with the pressure on a3.
D. A mistake as it affords the blindfold player the opportunity of breaking through on the other flank. As Black's object is to draw if possible, he should have withheld his King's wing so as to block the opposite Pawns and by this retaining his guard on all sides.
Analyze step by step and explain your reasoning.
Finish with a single line formatted EXACTLY as:
FINAL ANSWER: <answer>

question:
You are given a chess position in FEN: r1b1k2r/ppp1bppp/2pn4/4R3/8/3P1N2/PPP2PPP/RNB3K1 b kq - 0 10
A player makes the move: f7f6
Select the commentary that best describes this position and move.

Options:
A. Black is still far from equality. White not only has the more active placement of his pieces, but also enjoys the better possibilities to centralse his king, because of the shelter offered by the central e-pawn.
B. White probably thought that Black would have difficulty castling. In fact, Black demonstrates that his king is better placed than if it had already castled, as the position is tending toward an endgame and his king is already in the centre. Black's central pawn position -- or lack thereof -- is typical of the Steinitzian precedents, but here White still has ad-pawn. This gives him potentially better chances than the absence of both centre pawns, as the d-pawn may help support the knight at a variety of central posts, e.g., e4 or c4, although neither of these squares is absolutely secure
C. Black destroyed the pawn center giving him some counterplay. In spite of that White stands better, for the Black king which didn't castle yet is to much in jeopardy, allowing to many threats to be generated.
D. It is also possible to castle here, but White think the text and White's next two prophylactic moves form the most logical set-up. White prevents tactical breaks (notably those involving a quick b5) by solidly bolstering his c4 and e4 pawns. Most importantly since there is a high probability of a queen exchange on d2 following Black's Qa5, there is a strong case for keeping the king in the centre for the ensuing ending (or more properly perhaps 'queenless middlegame').
Analyze step by step and explain your reasoning.
Finish with a single line formatted EXACTLY as:
FINAL ANSWER: <answer>
Example format: FORMAT_EXAMPLE_PLACEHOLDER

D. Diagram [#] Black shows keen positional judgement. He could obtain two bishops versus two knights by the immediate capture at c3, but that would still leave him with a somewhat crippled queenside pawn structure. Instead, he prefers to play the knight to the outpost at d4. The knight will be so strongly placed that White will eventually be forced to exchange it and undouble Black's pawns, in which case Black will have added a substantial space advantage to the bishop pair.
Analyze step by step and explain your reasoning.

question:
You are given a chess position in FEN: 3N4/p5kp/1p2B1n1/4Pp2/5P2/4K2b/PP6/8 b - - 2 46
A player makes the move: g6e7
Select the commentary that best describes this position and move.

Options:
A. White's strong passed pawn promises him good compensation for one of the missing pawns, but probably not more. However, it is also not easy for Black to convert the advantage. Black tried to exchange Black's queenside pawns for the monster on e6 and to win the rook endgame but Black's opponent was not very willing to allow that.
B. Black has defended his inferior position well. White, however, still has the advantage because Black's pieces are tied down to the necessary blockade of the passed pawn. It is hard to say whether White's advantage , in theory, is enough to win, but in practical over the board play, the onus of accurate defence generally proves the defender's undoing, especially in a time pressure situation.
C. Black has managed to maintain his minimal material advantage and avoid the exchange of rooks at the same time. However, his extra pawn is hardly relevant and his last remaining chance consists of creating some threats against the enemy king, possibly combined with the relative lack of stability of the enemy bishop along the b1-e4 diagonal. We can see that White's advantage in space finally does him a good service. If we lift the whole king side structure with, say, 2 ranks, Black would get reasonable winning chances, one of the possible ideas being the exchange sacrifice in order to remove White's last pawn.
D. Black has achieved a solid defensive setup and Black was probably expecting a draw offer reasonable soon. White, however, plugs away and goes close to creating serious winning chances. His advantage lies in the fact that Black cannot afford to exchange all the minor pieces as then White's protected passed pawn will be a decisive factor in the pawn ending. Not a great deal to work with, I agree, but the need to avoid exchanges is certainly an inhibiting factor on Black.
Analyze step by step and explain your reasoning.
Finish with a single line formatted EXACTLY as:
FINAL ANSWER: <answer>
Example format: FORMAT_EXAMPLE_PLACEHOLDER

question:

Select the commentary that best describes this position and move.

Options:
A. White spent on this natural move more than ten minutes. He must have considered the knight retreats to g3 and c3, coming to the conclusion that it is too early to define his intentions regarding the knight. White has an active position, but needs to play with precision. If his initiative vanishes, he could even get some problems, due to his (now strong) d5-pawn.
B. White's pieces and pawns have reached their optimum squares and he must now find a plan. White's next few moves indicate either time trouble or a singular lack of ideas.
C. White has won some more space. The pawns on c5 and g5 are limiting Black's pieces to the last 2 ranks. The next step in White's plan is to regroup his pieces. Black has no counterplay whatsoever and has to wait.
D. Optically, White has compensation for the missing pawns, but he would badly need a knight to take advantage of Black's weaknesses. The next phase was played in mutual time trouble.

question:
You are given a chess position in FEN: 8/p2Bn3/1p1N2kp/4Pp2/1P3P2/P3K3/8/5b2 w - - 12 61
A player makes the move: d7e6
Select the commentary that best describes this position and move.

Options:
A. Black is running short of moves. His king and knight are tied to the f pawn, his bishop is on its best diagonal (preventing Nb5) and his queenside pawns are at their best, vulnerable. That leaves the h pawn, yet if Black plays h4 White simply returns his bishop to e8 and his knight to the kingside and infiltrates through the newly weakened g5 square. Black is forced to make a concession and he succeeds in finding the least evil.
B. Black missed this move from afar. Now Black has no counterplay. Moreover, Black's king, knight and e7-pawn are all poorly placed.
C. With the weak pawns on g7 and h6 fixed by the pawn h5, Black has to spend time playing g7-g6 exchanging the pawn on h5. But then the black king will be far away from the queenside. And the white pawn on a3 will become very dangerous. Even with reduced material on the board and the favourable colour of the a8-square it is not possible for Black to save the game.
D. Black's position is hard to play now. During the game White still assumed there was some way for Black to equalize but White could not find it. Black has to take into account moves like axb5, dxe5 and h4. With White, it is easy: White's next moves are probably Re1 and Qf3, against pretty much anything Black does, or even include Kh2 to slightly improve the king.
Analyze step by step and explain your reasoning.
Finish with a single line formatted EXACTLY as:
FINAL ANSWER: <answer>
Example format: FORMAT_EXAMPLE_PLACEHOLDER

A player makes the move: b4b5
Select the commentary that best describes this position and move.

Options:
A. As a result of White's 8th move he is saddled with a weakling on c3, which will prove a constant source of worry. White probably thinks he is attacking here, but Black can easily parry the little threat there is and bide his time to take advantage of White's weakened pawn structure.
B. A strong move that gives White a dangerous initiative. The White king is slightly weakened, but Black does not have time to exploit this. In the event of an exchange of queens later on it's an advantage for White having the c-pawn moved forward.
C. This is the initial move of a decisive manoeuvre. After the exchange at c6 and of a Rook White will be able to attack the weak Pawn c7 in superior force. This should have been the end.
D. A very interesting positional decision by White who deliberately helps his opponent to get rid of his weak pawn on c5 while his minor pieces will no longer have to guard it.. On the other hand Black's pawns on the queenside (a7,c6) become possible targets while the d-ile opens up with White having the better chances of getting the control of it.
Analyze step by step and explain your reasoning.
Finish with a single line formatted EXACTLY as:
FINAL ANSWER: <answer>

question:
You are given a chess position in FEN: 1r1qnk2/2p5/1pPp4/3Pp2p/2P1P2p/2N2PK1/8/R1Q5 w - - 0 43
A player makes the move: g3h3
Select the commentary that best describes this position and move.

Options:
A. The possibilities are many and quite bewildering. The play evolves around Black's quest for compensation for the pawn. White is often forced to give the pawn back, but then he can usually get a slight advantage. White has the following alternatives:
B. With little time left White saw Nh2, but also saw that in the end of the line when he will capture White's bishop White can enter a winning pawn endgame after exchanging the queens.
C. White resigned, since he is forced to play Qg6, when Black takes on g2, exchanges queens and wins the endgame with two pawns up. A very resilient game from Black, who was holding on to a slightly inferior position, took his chance when it appeared on the board, and was able to squeeze a win against one of the Top 10 players in the world!
D. The Pawn is only surrendered temporarily, as evidently White quickly recovers it with the Queen. Whites winning chance now consists in the fact, that in most lines of play he can invite exchange of Queens with a won end-game. Black has a very difficult game to play and his method of conducting it merits only praise.
Analyze step by step and explain your reasoning.
Finish with a single line formatted EXACTLY as:
FINAL ANSWER: <answer>
Example format: FORMAT_EXAMPLE_PLACEHOLDER

Options:
A. Plausible, but in the light of the preceding remark, it would have been wiser to play 22 Qc1 or 22 Qd2, although in either case Black would have regained his pawn with advantage.
B. Black continues to complicate matters. The best was probably to play 22 Nc6 winning back the exchange with a slightly worse position.
C. Perhaps a bit hasty. White could also play unconventionally. After the game Black suggested 23 f3 with a big advantage for White. White probably underestimated White's position. Black's king is stuck in the corner on h8 which could have been used to White's advantage.
D. With hindsight a very easy move to criticise, but as Black pointed out at the press conference, this exactly should be the one. To him it looked like now was the perfect timing, as White due to the weakness of the e4-pawn still seemingly needs a move to consolidate before taking aggressive measures. That premise being wrong, Black's best would have been to seek counterplay with 28 exf4 29 gxf4 Nc5, the idea being 30 e5 Nd3! with Black still being in the game.
Analyze step by step and explain your reasoning.

question:
You are given a chess position in FEN: rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1
A player makes the move: c2c4
Select the commentary that best describes this position and move.

Options:
A. Copyright 1992, ChessBase USA. Games and notes based on White Nimzovich's Chess Praxis (1936). In the opening, White teaches us to develop our pieces, control the center, and guard our king's long-term safety.
B. Playing f4-f5 too early, White breaks a very important chess principle. It is bad to begin concrete active play when you are behind in development. If you look at the white pieces you can see that the Nd2 and Bc1 are still not developed while Black has completely finished the development of his pieces. So playing f4-f5 too early, White has no chances for an advantage. Such chess principles are too easy to understand, but very often they are ignored (or not known) by young players.
C. Revealing the concept of White's play - attack on the king!
D. White is preparing the typical pawn sacrifice in the centre. But it was possible to execute it immediately. Usually in White's games White tries to follow the following principle - first to improve the position to a maximum, only then to start concrete play.
Analyze step by step and explain your reasoning.
Finish with a single line formatted EXACTLY as:
FINAL ANSWER: <answer>
